actions-list.actionItem: The House adjourned pursuant to a previous special order. The next meeting is scheduled for 10:00 a.m. on May 11, 2023.
On motion to adjourn Agreed to by voice vote.
Mr. Schweikert moved that the House do now adjourn.
The House has concluded all anticipated legislative business and has proceeded to Special Order speeches.
The House proceeded with further one minute speeches.

Mr. Green (TN) asked unanimous consent That when the House adjourns on Wednesday, May 10, 2023, it adjourn to meet at 10:00 a.m. on Thursday, May 11, 2023, for Morning-Hour debate and 11:00 a.m. for legislative business. Agreed to without objection.
Pursuant to clause 1(c) of rule XIX, the Chair announced further proceedings on H.R. 2 would be postponed.
The House proceeded with five hours of debate on H.R. 2.

Rule provides for consideration of H.R. 2 and H.R. 1163. The resolution provides for consideration of H.R. 2 under a closed rule with five hours of general debate, and the resolution provides for consideration of H.R. 1163 under a closed rule with one hour of general debate. The resolution provides for a motion to recommit on each measure.
Considered under the provisions of rule H. Res. 383. H.R. 2 — "To secure the borders of the United States, and for other purposes."
On approving the Journal Agreed to by voice vote.
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.

actions-list.header: On agreeing to the resolution Agreed to by recorded vote: 215

actions-list.actionItem: Considered as unfinished business. H. Res. 383 — "Providing for consideration of the bill (H.R. 2) to secure the borders of the United States, and for other purposes, and providing for consideration of the bill (H.R. 1163) to provide incentives for States to recover fraudulently paid Federal and State unemployment compensation, and for other purposes."
The Chair announced the unfinished business was the question on agreeing to H. Res. 383, as amended, which had been debated earlier and on which further proceedings had been postponed.
The House convened, returning from a recess continuing the legislative day of May 10.
The Speaker announced that the House do now recess. The next meeting is subject to the call of the Chair.
Pursuant to H. Res. 321, the Chair announced that the House would take a brief recess to prepare for the official photo of the House of Representatives while in session.

The Chair put the question on agreeing to H. Res. 383 and by voice vote, announced that the ayes had prevailed. Ms. Scanlon demanded a recorded vote and the Chair postponed further proceedings until a time to be announced.

actions-list.header: On agreeing to the Roy amendment; Agreed to by recorded vote: 236

actions-list.actionItem: On ordering the previous question on the amendment (A001) and the resolution. Agreed to by the Yeas and Nays: 215-211 (Roll no. 205)
An amendment, offered by Mr. Roy,  to add a new section to the end of the resolution to amend language in H.R. 2.
The House proceeded with one hour of debate on H. Res. 383.

Considered as privileged matter. H. Res. 383 — "Providing for consideration of the bill (H.R. 2) to secure the borders of the United States, and for other purposes, and providing for consideration of the bill (H.R. 1163) to provide incentives for States to recover fraudulently paid Federal and State unemployment compensation, and for other purposes."
The House convened, returning from a recess continuing the legislative day of May 10.
The Speaker announced that the House do now recess. The next meeting is subject to the call of the Chair.

actions-list.header: The Speaker laid before the House a message from the President transmitting a notification stating that the national emergency declared in Executive Order 13873 of May 15, 2019, with respect to securing the information and communications technology and services supply chain, is to continue in effect beyond May 15, 2023
actions-list.actionItem: referred to the Committee on Foreign Affairs and ordered to be printed (H. Doc. 118-39).

actions-list.header: The Speaker laid before the House a message from the President transmitting a notification of the continuation of the national emergency with respect to the Central African Republic declared in Executive Order 13667 of May 12, 2014, is to continue in effect beyond May 12, 2023
actions-list.actionItem: referred to the Committee on Foreign Affairs and ordered to be printed (H. Doc. 118-38).

The House received a message from the Clerk. Pursuant to section 1(k) of House Resolution 895, 110th Congress, and section 4(d) of House Resolution 5, 118th Congress, the Clerk notified the House that the following individuals each have signed an agreement not to be a candidate for the office of Senator or Represenative in, or Delegate or Resident Commissioner to, the Congress for the purposes of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 until at least 3 years after they are no longer a member of the board or staff of the Office of Congressional Ethics: Michael D. Barnes, Paul Vinovich, Lynn Westmoreland, Lorraine C. Miller, William H. Cable, Annie Cho, William P. Luther, Helen Eisner, Karen L. Haas, Kristina M. Crump, Docktrel Cromartie, Omar Ashmawy, Caleb S. Moore, Aaron Wilensky, Indhira Benitez.

actions-list.header: General Counsel of the United States House of Representatives
actions-list.actionItem: Pursuant to clause 8 of rule 2, and the order of the House of January 9, 2023, the Speaker appointed Matthew B. Berry.
The House resumed with one minute speeches.
The House received a message from the Senate. The Senate passed H.R. 346 amended.
The House proceeded with one minute speeches, which by direction of the Chair, would be limited to 15 per side of the aisle.
The Chair designated Mr. Correa to lead the Members in reciting the Pledge of Allegiance to the Flag.

The Chair announced that he had examined the Journal of the last day's proceedings and had approved it. Mr. Wilson (SC) demanded that the question be put on agreeing to the Speaker's approval of the Journal and by voice vote, the Chair announced that the ayes had prevailed. Mr. Wilson (SC) objected to the voice vote based upon the absence of a quorum and the Chair postponed further proceedings on the question of agreeing to the Speaker's approval of the Journal until a time to be announced.
Today's prayer was offered by the House Chaplain, Chaplain Margaret Grun Kibben.
The House convened, returning from a recess continuing the legislative day of May 10.
The Speaker announced that the House do now recess. The next meeting is scheduled for 12:00 P.M. today.
The House proceeded with Morning-Hour Debate. At the conclusion of Morning-Hour, the House will recess until 12:00 p.m. for the start of legislative business.
The Speaker designated the Honorable Michelle Steel to act as Speaker pro tempore for today.
The House convened, starting a new legislative day.
